high_risk_jurisdictions.name: High-Risk Jurisdictions subject to a Call for Action ('Black List')
high_risk_jurisdictions.description: Jurisdictions with significant strategic deficiencies in their regimes to counter money laundering, terrorist financing, and financing of proliferation. The FATF calls on all members and urges all jurisdictions to apply enhanced due diligence, and in the most serious cases, countermeasures.

main_deficiencies: Continued failure to address significant AML/CFT deficiencies
Serious threats related to proliferation of weapons of mass destruction
countermeasures: Terminate correspondent relationships with DPRK banks
Close any subsidiaries or branches of DPRK banks
Limit business relationships & financial transactions with DPRK persons

main_deficiencies: Failure to enact the Palermo and Terrorist Financing Conventions
Failure to complete its action plan from 2016
jurisdictions.notes: Iran reported in January, August and December 2024 with no material changes in the status of its action plan.

main_deficiencies: Continued lack of progress on action plan items
Majority of action items still not addressed after a year beyond deadline
jurisdictions.status: If no further progress is made by June 2025, the FATF will consider countermeasures.

increased_monitoring_jurisdictions.name: Jurisdictions under Increased Monitoring ('Grey List')
increased_monitoring_jurisdictions.description: Jurisdictions under increased monitoring are actively working with the FATF to address strategic deficiencies in their regimes to counter money laundering, terrorist financing, and proliferation financing.

key_deficiencies: Improving risk-based supervision, especially for higher risk sectors
Developing framework for beneficial ownership information
Enhancing suspicious transaction reports regime
Establishing effective framework for targeted financial sanctions for terrorism financing
Implementing risk-based approach to oversight of NPOs
Enhancing understanding of ML/TF risks
Improving risk-based supervision of non-financial banking entities and DNFBPs
Ensuring access to beneficial ownership information
Demonstrating increase in ML investigations and prosecutions
Demonstrating ability to identify, investigate and prosecute TF
Demonstrating effective implementation of targeted financial sanctions
Addressing technical compliance deficiencies
Improving investigations and prosecutions of different types of money laundering
Ensuring parallel financial investigations in terrorism investigations
Addressing gaps in the PF TFS frameworks
Demonstrating risk-based monitoring of NPOs
Implementing an effective targeted financial sanctions regime related to TF and PF
jurisdictions.notes: All deadlines have expired (December 2022) and work remains
